docs.lead_paragraph: Hordes of consumers, often called ''the worried wealthy,'' are flocking to medical centers and mobile trailers around the country to have their bodies scanned by three-dimensional computerized X-rays from chest to groin. They are not sent by physicians, and most have no symptoms to warrant exposing themselves to radiation doses that may add up to the equivalent of 500 chest X-rays, the National Radiological Protection Board says.

headline.main: How Perils Can Await the 'Worried Wealthy'

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column says wealthy individuals may be ill advised to pay unreimbursable sums for total body CT scans just to reassure themselves that nothing is wrong internally that would warrant prompt treatment; says no one has yet published study to document value and safety of scans for ostensibly well people; says CT scans were developed to serve as aids in diagnosis, not blind searches for what may or may not be wrong with patient; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Helping others may help older people live longer, according to a study being released today by the University of Michigan. The study, by researchers at the university's Institute for Social Research, looked at 423 men over 65 and their wives. People who described themselves as providing either emotional support to a spouse or tangible help to someone in another household were roughly half as likely to die in the five years that followed as those who did neither, the study found.

headline.main: Help Others, for a Longer Life

docs.abstract: University of Michigan study suggests that helping others may help older people live longer; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jose Martinez, a 29-year-old Dominican immigrant who runs a bodega on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, almost always manages to find whatever his customers need on his store's bulging shelves. When asked for medicine for an infection, Mr. Martinez often reaches for a box of pills called Ampitrex, a brand name for the antibiotic ampicillin.

headline.main: No Prescription for Antibiotics? No Problem

docs.abstract: Easy access to antibiotics from abroad is now common in certain areas around US, and this alarms many health officials, who fear that some people may take wrong antibiotic and worsen their infection or have allergic reaction or that not taking full course of antibiotics will allow bacteria to develop resistance to antibiotic; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In treating hemorrhaging cerebral aneurysms -- burst blood vessels in the brain -- there are two camps: the clippers and the coilers. A recent study in The Lancet, a London-based medical publication, has come out strongly in favor of coiling, a nonsurgical method far more popular in Europe than it is in the United States.
docs.abstract: Study reported in Lancet finds that 31 percent of patients treated surgically for cerebral aneurysm are disabled or dead as a result, compared with 24 percent for those treated with nonsurgical method called coiling; coiling was invented in US but is performed far more often in Europe; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In treating hemorrhaging cerebral aneurysms -- burst blood vessels in the brain -- there are two camps: the clippers and the coilers.    A recent study in The Lancet, a London-based medical publication, has come out strongly in favor of coiling, a...

docs.lead_paragraph: To cut down on drug errors affecting heart patients, doctors should use computers more and handwriting less, an American Heart Association panel reported yesterday. The panel's work, published in the journal Circulation, also called for a mandatory system for reporting medication errors and greater efforts to teach doctors about drugs with names that are confusingly similar.
docs.abstract: American Heart Assn advises doctors to use computers more and handwriting less in writing prescriptions for heart patients; says drug errors are particularly troublesome in cardiology because field relies heavily on ever-changing and broad list of medicines (S)
docs.snippet: To cut down on drug errors affecting heart patients, doctors should use computers more and handwriting less, an American Heart Association panel reported yesterday.     The panel's work, published in the journal Circulation, also called for a...

docs.lead_paragraph: At 38, my patient Michael had reached the top of his profession but was having a lot of trouble getting along with his colleagues. They were, he revealed, afraid of his angry outbursts, which could be provoked by the faintest of criticism from them. Then in one session I got a taste of his rage myself. Feeling that I had been critical of his treatment of a subordinate at work, his usually pleasant manner abruptly changed. Glowering, he clenched his teeth and began to crush a Diet Coke can with his hands before letting lose a stream of expletives. He was having a rage attack.

headline.main: Beyond Anger: Studying the Subconscious Nature of Rage

docs.abstract: Richard A Friedman article on anger; says that while human brain comes hard-wired for anger and rage and can become gripped by rage without consciously perceiving why, most people are able to control these impulses; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cancer patients are often told that a positive attitude can lengthen their lives. But a new survey of existing research found little evidence that mental outlook makes a difference in outcome. The study, published last week in BMJ, the journal of the British Medical Association, reviewed 37 studies that examined the relationship among fighting spirit, feelings of helplessness or hopelessness, denial, stoicism and other coping styles on death from cancer or its recurrence.

headline.main: Attitudes, in the Face of Death

docs.abstract: British study finds no support for idea that positive attitude can help cancer patients survive their disease or prevent its recurrence; authors say that while there are good reasons to have positive mental attitude, people should not be pressured to have one if they do not (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Crosswalks that are not paired with traffic lights or stop signs appear to make intersections more dangerous instead of safer, at least for older pedestrians, a new study says. The study, published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association, looked at 282 intersections in Washington State and California where pedestrians over 65 had been hit and compared them with 564 other nearby intersections.
docs.abstract: Study finds that crosswalks that are not paired with traffic lights or stop signs may make intersections more dangerous instead of safer, perhaps because crosswalks are more visible to pedestrians than to drivers; drawing (S)
